{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3500204,"name":"Ethan Grieshop","username":"CakeDeer6","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cakedeer6/{size}/264680_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-02T22:09:30.482Z","cooked":"

We recently reprogrammed our 2024 robot and came across an issue similar to one we had last year and were never able to solve. No matter how many times we retuned our drivetrain pid, verified gear ratios, and remeasured constants like wheel diameter and drive base length, our odometry still had significant drift. This issue persists this year, despite the code being rewritten in a completely different language.

When we drive 6m forward and 5m back to the same position, the bot will be ~30cm off, and doing the same with a 2m travel in each direction leads to a 15cm drift.

Are we approaching the upper limit on what is possible with pure odometry (no vision)? If not, are there things that we could do to improve accuracy, or is it likely that there’s something physically wrong with our drivetrain?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2025-02-02T22:09:30.482Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":21,"reads":376,"readers_count":375,"score":210.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":484839,"topic_slug":"what-s-the-upper-ceiling-for-odometry-accuracy","display_username":"Ethan Grieshop","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62698,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4611 Programmer + Driver"},"post_url":"/t/what-s-the-upper-ceiling-for-odometry-accuracy/484839/1","custom_user_title":"4611 Programmer + Driver","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":3500212,"name":"Eric Ward","username":"bathtubed","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bathtubed/{size}/220364_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-02T22:23:40.216Z","cooked":"

The upper ceiling is definitely higher than at least that.
To be honest, just driving forward and backward should result in 0 drift, assuming the swerve modules don’t turn 180 degrees at the inflection point.

Assuming you drive forward, and then drive backward with the wheels staying straight, the drive encoders should reverse all their motion and should be at 0 right when you reach the start point again.

This is an experiment you should try to verify because otherwise that indicates a bug in the code.

However assuming that works fine, there’s a host of other potential sources of error/bias that can be accounted for. I would say you aren’t near the upper limit, I would expect drift of less than 10cm for such experiments

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2025-02-02T22:23:40.216Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":14,"reads":358,"readers_count":357,"score":171.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":484839,"topic_slug":"what-s-the-upper-ceiling-for-odometry-accuracy","display_username":"Eric Ward","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":35208,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3637 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/what-s-the-upper-ceiling-for-odometry-accuracy/484839/2","custom_user_title":"3637 Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":true,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3500213,"name":"Wolly :)","username":"wolly_efendi","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/wolly_efendi/{size}/165245_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-02T22:23:49.028Z","cooked":"

I would assume the biggest culprit of the error is wheel slip. The robot “thinks” it is at the right spot because the wheel has turned the correct number of revolutions but in reality some of those turns did not actually translate the robot as the wheels slipped. You can decrease the acceleration to try to eliminate this but especially with lateral movements involved you’re going to have wheel slip. That’s some of the “slop” that vision corrects for.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2025-02-02T22:23:49.028Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":339,"readers_count":338,"score":67.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":484839,"topic_slug":"what-s-the-upper-ceiling-for-odometry-accuracy","display_username":"Wolly :)","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":49878,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/what-s-the-upper-ceiling-for-odometry-accuracy/484839/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3500352,"name":"Chadfrom7226","username":"Chadfrom7226","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/chadfrom7226/{size}/113429_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-03T01:56:34.052Z","cooked":"

I know you said no vision, but a vision system help help correct odometry error, and it’s not super hard anymore to do that

We could barely get through an auton routine last year without it being off by too much to score / pick up

This year we’re adding vision to correct and it seems to be working pretty well

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2025-02-03T01:58:40.534Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":268,"readers_count":267,"score":58.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":484839,"topic_slug":"what-s-the-upper-ceiling-for-odometry-accuracy","display_username":"Chadfrom7226","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":20021,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/what-s-the-upper-ceiling-for-odometry-accuracy/484839/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3500353,"name":"Ethan Grieshop","username":"CakeDeer6","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cakedeer6/{size}/264680_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-03T01:57:49.805Z","cooked":"

We have a great vision system, but the error in odometry builds up too fast for localization to be as reliable as we want.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2025-02-03T01:57:49.805Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":250,"readers_count":249,"score":55.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":484839,"topic_slug":"what-s-the-upper-ceiling-for-odometry-accuracy","display_username":"Ethan Grieshop","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":20021,"username":"Chadfrom7226","name":"Chadfrom7226","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/chadfrom7226/{size}/113429_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62698,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4611 Programmer + Driver"},"post_url":"/t/what-s-the-upper-ceiling-for-odometry-accuracy/484839/5","custom_user_title":"4611 Programmer + Driver","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3500355,"name":"Chadfrom7226","username":"Chadfrom7226","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/chadfrom7226/{size}/113429_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-03T01:59:33.263Z","cooked":"

What vision system are you using? It should correct for odometry errors.

We use photonvision with AdvantageKit’s vision and swerve templates

Vision isn’t the issue. Our odometry is so bad, that doing simple things like lining up to the reef, aren’t possible because we lose our position by the time the apriltag leaves our view

What are you using for swerve (yagsl, custom, etc.)? If your robot characteristics are correct I cant imagine why you would get so much inaccuracy from just driving regularly/simple alignment

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2025-02-03T02:20:43.511Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":221,"readers_count":220,"score":49.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":484839,"topic_slug":"what-s-the-upper-ceiling-for-odometry-accuracy","display_username":"Otto","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":62698,"username":"CakeDeer6","name":"Ethan Grieshop","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cakedeer6/{size}/264680_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":59898,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/what-s-the-upper-ceiling-for-odometry-accuracy/484839/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3500404,"name":"Ethan Grieshop","username":"CakeDeer6","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cakedeer6/{size}/264680_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-03T03:04:47.444Z","cooked":"

Custom. We use the wpilib swerve trajectories class.

If you slow the speeds and accelerations down (to 50% or 30%), does the odometry’s accuracy improve? If so, it’s probably wheel slip. If not, it’s probably something wrong in the config/constants/integration.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2025-02-03T03:36:47.588Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":180,"readers_count":179,"score":41.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":484839,"topic_slug":"what-s-the-upper-ceiling-for-odometry-accuracy","display_username":"Jim Sokoloff","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":62698,"username":"CakeDeer6","name":"Ethan Grieshop","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cakedeer6/{size}/264680_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":66298,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"97 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/what-s-the-upper-ceiling-for-odometry-accuracy/484839/10","custom_user_title":"97 Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3500440,"name":"Ethan Grieshop","username":"CakeDeer6","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cakedeer6/{size}/264680_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-03T03:40:37.515Z","cooked":"

We get pretty similar error at low speeds, but we have coded the bot twice independently and saw the same issue both times.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2025-02-03T03:40:37.515Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":169,"readers_count":168,"score":38.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":484839,"topic_slug":"what-s-the-upper-ceiling-for-odometry-accuracy","display_username":"Ethan Grieshop","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":66298,"username":"sokoloff","name":"Jim Sokoloff","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sokoloff/{size}/231724_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62698,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4611 Programmer + Driver"},"post_url":"/t/what-s-the-upper-ceiling-for-odometry-accuracy/484839/11","custom_user_title":"4611 Programmer + Driver","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3500448,"name":"Kabir","username":"kn4","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kn4/{size}/235296_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-03T03:50:35.581Z","cooked":"

How are you measuring the wheel radius? Worn tread can result in changed wheel diameters. The AdvantageKit swerve template has a routine that spins the robot in a circle and uses the gyroscope angle to determine the effective wheel radius.
You might also want to put the robot on blocks so that the wheels freely spin and verify the drive/odometry behavior there. Make sure everything moves in the same direction, make sure the wheel rotations read in the code match with the actual wheel, etc.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2025-02-03T03:50:35.581Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":163,"readers_count":162,"score":142.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":484839,"topic_slug":"what-s-the-upper-ceiling-for-odometry-accuracy","display_username":"Kabir","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://github.com/Mechanical-Advantage/AdvantageKit/blob/main/template_projects/sources/spark_swerve/src/main/java/frc/robot/commands/DriveCommands.java#L224","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"AdvantageKit/template_projects/sources/spark_swerve/src/main/java/frc/robot/commands/DriveCommands.java at main · Mechanical-Advantage/AdvantageKit · GitHub","clicks":7}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57470,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2724 programmer"},"post_url":"/t/what-s-the-upper-ceiling-for-odometry-accuracy/484839/12","custom_user_title":"2724 programmer","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3500686,"name":"Chadfrom7226","username":"Chadfrom7226","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/chadfrom7226/{size}/113429_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-03T15:47:49.274Z","cooked":"

Could you use a swerve library like YAGSL, Phoenix Tuner, Rev Robotics? Or is your swerve custom for a reason?

Not sure what would cause it to be off

  • Is the gearing set correctly?
  • Is the wheel radius actually the radius or did you accidentally put the diameter in for radius
  • Are all your wheels pointing the same direction when trying to go straight?
  • Can you add a fudge-factor constant that fixes the odometry issue or is it not a consistent enough where a fudge factor would work?
  • Is the Front left/ front right/ back left/ back right set correctly?

Odometry should be decently close if all the math is done correctly
